messageBody:
What I've found works best (at least in the situations I have
encountered) is to have the main parser actually delegate to a number of
sub-parsers. That is, if for example one thing you need to parse is a
color specification, extract that logic into a ColorParser. That makes
it both easier to test in isolation, easier to read and maintain and
more reusable.

Does that help?

Cheers, Ilja

sunburned.surveyor wrote:
> I'm still rather new to JUnit (although I've purchased at least two
> (2) JUnit books)and I'm finally getting around to actually using unit
> tests for my code.
>
> I've ran into a puzzling situation, and I'm looking for suggestions
> on how to [1] properly test code using JUnit or [2] refactor my code
> so that it can be tested.
>
> The class in question parses a fairly complex text file and
> constructs a single Java object from it. There is a single public
> parse method that returns an instance of this object. Inside this
> public parse method several private helper methods are called.
> Basically the job of the public method is to call the private helper
> methods in the correct sequence, based on the contents of the file
> being parsed.
>
> Here is my question: I want to verify that the logic in parts of
> these private helper methods does what I intend. Although I know a
> failure of any of these "logic parts" in a private helper method
> would be reflected in a failure of the public method. However, I want
> to pinpoint which of the "logic parts" failing.
>
> Have I left the realm of unit testing and moved on to some type of
> functional testing? Do I need to refactor these "logic parts" into
> their own private methods, and then use a framework like JUnitX to
> test these private methods? Do I write some beanshell scripts that
> test this logic instead?
>
> Thanks for any suggestions on how to proceed. I know this problem is
> due to my lack of experience with software testing, and is not a
> problem with JUnit.
>
> The Sunburned Surveyor
